title: Thursday, 8:30 a.m.
Talking with Our Publics: Engagement and Accountability
text: Program arranged by the MLA Committee on the Status of Women in the Profession. Presiding: Angelika Bammer, Emory Univ.; Rosemary G. Feal, MLA; Liana Silva-Ford, Houston, TX

Good communication skills are critical to our roles as scholars, teachers, and public intellectuals. On-campus colleagues and the general public often wonder what we do and why. We need to be able to respond. This workshop focuses on communicating our work with two kinds of publics—the media and a general, nonspecialist audience—and is divided into two parts, each facilitated by an expert. Preregistration required.

title: Careers for Humanists: A Job Search Workshop
text: Program arranged by the MLA Office of Research. Presiding: Jennifer Furlong, Graduate Center, City Univ. of New York; Christine Kelly, Univ. of California, Irvine; Katina Rogers, Graduate Center, City Univ. of New York

This workshop is designed for graduate students and others interested in pursuing new career options outside the classroom or outside the academy; it focuses on practical strategies for conducting such a job search—preparing application materials, networking, negotiating an offer, and more. Preregistration required.

title: Critical DH (Digital Humanities) Interventions in Scholarly Communications and Publishing
text: A special session. Presiding: Raymond G. Siemens, Univ. of Victoria

Speakers: Juan Pablo Alperin, Simon Fraser Univ.; Alyssa Arbuckle, Univ. of Victoria; Nina Belojevic, Univ. of Victoria; Matthew Hiebert, Univ. of Victoria; Shaun MacPherson, Univ. of Victoria; Alec Smecher, Simon Fraser Univ.

This workshop considers innovative ways DH engages scholarly communication and publishing. Contents (theoretical and hands-on): social knowledge construction and critical making; digital cooperatives and scholarly editions; user interface and experience; peer-review personas; Scalar; Git and GitHub; Open Monograph Press; social academic community development. Preregistration required.
For full program and ancillary materials, visit dhsi.org.

title: Thursday, 11:45 a.m.
Preconvention Workshop for Job Seekers in English
text: Program arranged by the ADE Executive Committee. Presiding: Malin Pereira, Univ. of North Carolina, Charlotte
Speakers: Kent Cartwright, Univ. of Maryland, College Park; Sandra Sellers Hanson, LaGuardia Community Coll., City Univ. of New York; Cynthia Scheinberg, Mills Coll.

Representatives from different types of institutions will discuss aspects of the job search, including career paths for tenure-track and non-tenure-track faculty members; letters of application and recommendation; curricula vitae; interviews at the convention, via Skype or phone, and on campus; multiyear job search strategies; and negotiating an offer.

title: Preconvention Workshop for Job Seekers in Foreign Languages
text: Program arranged by the ADFL Executive Committee. Presiding: Sibelan Forrester, Swarthmore Coll.
Speakers: Maggie Childs, Univ. of Kansas; Omar Ka, Univ. of Maryland Baltimore County; June Miyasaki, Los Angeles Valley Coll., CA; Karen A. Stolley, Emory Univ.

Representatives of different institutional types discuss work and career paths in AA-, BA-, MA-, and PhD-granting programs and institutions. Speakers address institutional expectations and aspects of the job search: the application dossier, interviews at the convention and on campus, waiting out a sluggish market, and negotiating an offer.

This roundtable explores the role of praxis in the academy through the fields of postcolonial studies and the digital humanities. Participants discuss how they actively integrate the methodologies of postcolonial analysis into the digital humanities, revealing the implicit presence of race, ethnicity, and systems of exclusion.

title: Literature/Film: Disciplinary Tensions
text: A special session. Presiding: Nora Gilbert, Univ. of North Texas

Speakers: Juan Alonzo, Texas A&M Univ., College Station; Deborah Barker, Univ. of Mississippi; Aviva Briefel, Bowdoin Coll.; Tom Clark Conley, Harvard Univ.; Jonathan E. Freedman, Univ. of Michigan, Ann Arbor; Sarah O'Brien, Univ. of Toronto

This roundtable reports on the status of one type of interdisciplinary study: that which integrates literary and film analysis. Is this brand of interdisciplinarity still encouraged now that more and more universities are creating separate film programs? Literature-film scholars offer insight into how this bimodality affects one’s chances on the job market, on the tenure track, and in publishing.

title: The Comics of Joe Sacco: Journalism in a Visual World
text: A special session. Presiding: Daniel W. Worden, Univ. of New Mexico, Albuquerque
Speakers: Lan Dong, Univ. of Illinois, Springfield; Ann D'Orazio, Univ. of New Mexico, Albuquerque; Jared Gardner, Ohio State Univ., Columbus; Maureen Shay, Univ. of California, Los Angeles
Respondent: David M. Ball, Princeton Univ.

The roundtable brings together established and emerging scholars in comics studies to discuss an acclaimed contemporary comics artist, Joe Sacco. The discussion focuses on Sacco’s significance to both literary and comics studies, as well as the challenges that his “comics journalism” poses to the categories and methods of analysis in comics studies.

title: Transnational Futurism: Italy, Russia, and Beyond
text: Program arranged by the American Association of Teachers of Slavic and East European Languages. Presiding: Christine Poggi, Univ. of Pennsylvania
Speakers: Oleh Ilnytzkyj, Univ. of Alberta; Michael Kunichika, New York Univ.; Vaclav Paris, Univ. of Pennsylvania; Harsha Ram, Univ. of California, Berkeley

This roundtable analyzes the paradox of futurism—a truly international (and self-described "universal") movement yet also a contested terrain whose inhabitants could not find a common language. Brief presentations on the relations among various regional futurisms (Russian, Georgian, Ukrainian, Czech, Italian) and the broader futurist movement are followed by a general discussion.
For abstracts, visit mlaslavic.blogspot.com.

title: Toward a Global Academic Commons: Academic Freedom and Sites of Contested Speech
text: Program arranged by the MLA Delegate Assembly Organizing Committee. Presiding: Jennifer Wicke, Univ. of Virginia

Speakers: Dina Al-Kassim, Univ. of British Columbia, Vancouver; Colin Dayan, Vanderbilt Univ.; David C. Lloyd, Univ. of California, Riverside; David Palumbo-Liu, Stanford Univ.; Diana Taylor, New York Univ.

This roundtable considers the academic commons as a model for global academic exchange, for border crossing both literally and figuratively, and for the agency of the humanities writ large in the world—for what can be seen and what can be spoken. The panel addresses academic freedom in a global context, contemporary challenges to it from inside and outside the academy, and vital responses.

title: Keywords in Queer Studies
text: A special session. Presiding: Robyn Wiegman, Duke Univ.

Speakers: Zakiyyah Jackson, Univ. of Virginia; Annamarie Jagose, Univ. of Sydney; Uri McMillan, Univ. of California, Los Angeles; Amber Musser, Washington Univ. in St. Louis; Cindy Patton, Simon Fraser Univ.

By considering keywords as part of the conceptual drama and performative complexity of queer studies, this roundtable explores the historical and critical density of some of the most prominent terms that today’s practitioners are widely assumed to know, including normativity, identity, queer of color, and posthuman.

title: Remembering The Location of Culture: Circulations, Interventions, and Futurity
text: A special session. Presiding: Kavita Daiya, George Washington Univ.

Speakers: Deepika Bahri, Emory Univ.; Homi Bhabha, Harvard Univ.; Kavita Daiya; Keith Feldman, Univ. of California, Berkeley; Ranjana Khanna, Duke Univ.; Gautam Premnath, Univ. of Nevada, Reno; Henry Schwarz, Georgetown Univ.

This panel offers a retrospective on Homi Bhabha’s The Location of Culture, published in 1994 and subsequently reprinted globally in over fifteen languages and twenty-two countries. This panel instigates a capacious conversation about the influential and controversial The Location of Culture that looks back and forward.

Our roundtable draws from the different periods and nationalities of the nineteenth century to create a transatlantic approach to literary history informed by the materialist concerns of "media archaeology."

title: Using Your Language Proficiency and Cultural Expertise in a Federal Government Career
text: Program arranged by the MLA Office of Programs. Presiding: Richard Donovan, Defense Language Inst. Foreign Language Center

This workshop provides an overview of various federal careers that utilize skills in languages and cultural expertise—translator, interpreter, instructor, intelligence analyst, language analyst, foreign language program manager, foreign service officer, and law enforcement officer. Recruiters and subject matter experts discuss career opportunities and the application process. A question-and-answer period concludes the session.

title: Pursuing Two Passions: On Being a Graduate Student and Something Else
text: Program arranged by the Graduate Student Caucus. Presiding: Kristal Bivona, Univ. of California, Los Angeles

Speakers: Rebecca A. Lippman, Univ. of California, Los Angeles; Derek McGrath, Stony Brook Univ., State Univ. of New York; Alison Reed, Univ. of California, Santa Barbara; Dominick Rolle, Emory Univ.; Matthew Sherman, Univ. of Texas, Austin; Jessi Snider, Texas A&M Univ., College Station; Julie Williams, Univ. of New Mexico, Albuquerque

This roundtable explores the challenges and rewards of pursuing another passion concurrently with graduate study. Participants reflect on what it means to be a student and "something else," to lead a “double life,” in order to share approaches and tactics for being successful at both passions. Topics include alt-ac careers, having a family, activism, and hobbies.
For abstracts and participant biographies, visit www.graduatestudentcaucus.org/events.html.

title: English, British, Anglophone: What’s in a Name?
text: Program arranged by the Division on Twentieth-Century English Literature. Presiding: Priya Joshi, Temple Univ., Philadelphia

Speakers: Kevin J. H. Dettmar, Pomona Coll.; Susan Stanford Friedman, Univ. of Wisconsin, Madison; Jahan Ramazani, Univ. of Virginia; Urmila Seshagiri, Univ. of Tennessee, Knoxville; Rebecca L. Walkowitz, Rutgers Univ., New Brunswick

The MLA’s efforts to reorganize divisions around linguistic rather than national boundaries has inspired wide-ranging debate on how best to name writing in “English” that defies national, imperial, ethnic, and cultural provincialisms. What is in a name? A lot, and our roundtable is an opportunity to debate the issue.

title: The Future of the History of the English Language: Pedagogical Practices
text: A special session. Presiding: Mary Hayes, Univ. of Mississippi

A roundtable on teaching the history of the English language (HEL) and the challenges that arise despite and because of English’s global status and unprecedented media influence. Particular attention to how traditional approaches can include the burgeoning field of historical sociolinguistics, multimedia resources, and twenty-first-century Englishes.
For further information, visit www.futureofhel.com after 1 Nov.

title: Pre-1900 Native American Literatures and Aesthetics
text: A special session. Presiding: Angela Calcaterra, Univ. of West Florida
Speakers: Angela Calcaterra; Blake Hausman, Portland Community Coll., OR; Joanne van der Woude, Univ. of Groningen; Caroline Wigginton, Univ. of Mississippi; Kelly Wisecup, Univ. of North Texas

Despite widespread recognition of Native literary art beginning with the 1960s "Native American Renaissance," scholarship on pre-1900 indigenous literatures largely avoids questions of artistic value. This roundtable addresses such questions, discussing taste, beauty, creativity, and imagination in early Native writing, as well as the relation between aesthetics and politics.

title: H. G. Adler's Shoah Trilogy
text: A special session. Presiding: Peter Filkins, Bard Coll. at Simon's Rock

Speakers: Jeremy Adler, King's Coll. London; Christopher Browning, Univ. of North Carolina, Chapel Hill; Peter Filkins; Sara R. Horowitz, York Univ., Keele; Katrin Kohl, Univ. of Oxford, Jesus Coll.; Lynn Louise Wolff, Michigan State Univ.

Participants discuss H. G. Adler's Shoah trilogy (Panorama, The Journey, and The Wall), taking up the modernist complexity of Adler's rendering of his experience in Theresienstadt and Auschwitz as a means to memorialize those who were lost and to have their loss speak trenchantly and meaningfully to the present.
For a description of the roundtable, write to pfilkins@simons-rock.edu.

title: Analyzing Cultural Memory in a Multilayered Language and Literature Curriculum
text: Program arranged by the American Association of Teachers of German. Presiding: Gisela Ruth Hoecherl-Alden, Boston Univ.
Speakers: Peter Höyng, Emory Univ.; Timothy Bruce Malchow, Valparaiso Univ.; Jennifer Redmann, Franklin and Marshall Coll.

Literacy-oriented language programs overcome the language-literature bifurcation by creating a spiraled undergraduate curriculum to ensure that students revisit topics in greater depth as they progress in language proficiency. Through theme- and genre-based tasks, students analyze how literature creates and transmits cultural memory and shapes recollections of the past at every proficiency level.

title: Literary Science
text: Program arranged by the Division on Late-Eighteenth-Century English Literature. Presiding: William Beatty Warner, Univ. of California, Santa Barbara

Speakers: Peter L. de Bolla, Univ. of Cambridge, King's Coll.; Ian Duncan, Univ. of California, Berkeley; Sara Landreth, Univ. of Ottawa; Stephen Osadetz, Harvard Univ.; Clifford Haynes Siskin, New York Univ.; Robin Valenza, Univ. of Wisconsin, Madison

Instrumental defenses of the literary humanities in crisis will not make us central to the research agendas of the future. To clarify our contribution, we should return to the eighteenth century, when moral and natural philosophy were not as distant from each other as "humanities" and "science" are now. Then we can explore two key questions: How has literary science advanced knowledge? How should it?

title: Working with the Working Class: How Can the Academy Do Better?
text: A special session. Presiding: Martin B. Shichtman, Eastern Michigan Univ.

Speakers: Jason Gene Arthur, Rockhurst Univ.; Anne Clark Bartlett, DePaul Univ.; Laurie Anne Finke, Kenyon Coll.; Andrea Kaston Tange, Eastern Michigan Univ.; Tracie Morris, Pratt Inst.; Michael Carl Schoenfeldt, Univ. of Michigan, Ann Arbor

What are the stakes in academia for working-class undergraduates, graduate students, and junior faculty members? Recent books focus on anecdotes of working-class experience; this roundtable moves from anecdotal to practical—opening questions of mentoring, placement, retention, and collegiality to foster discussion of these issues.
For discussion questions and pre- and postconvention public conversation about issues, visit classintheacademy.commons.mla.org.

title: Negotiating Flesh as a Site of Memory: Reconsidering the Semantic Field of Hortense Spillers
text: A special session. Presiding: Selamawit Terrefe, Univ. of California, Irvine
Speakers: Kimberly Nichele Brown, Virginia Commonwealth Univ.; J. Kameron Carter, Duke Univ.; Jared Sexton, Univ. of California, Irvine; Christina Sharpe, Tufts Univ.; Selamawit Terrefe

A discussion about Spillers's concept of the "flesh"—a concept both highly specific to the captive black female in the historic instance of racial slavery and deliberately vague in its references to a theological-philosophical discourse on the body-flesh distinction—to negotiate rupture as a possible or impossible site of memory.

title: Translational Humboldt
text: A special session. Presiding: Susan Gillman, Univ. of California, Santa Cruz

Speakers: Ralph Bauer, Univ. of Maryland, College Park; Ottmar R. Ette, Univ. of Potsdam; Susan Gillman; Vera Kutzinski, Vanderbilt Univ.; Mark Person, Univ. of Wyoming; Laura Dassow Walls, Univ. of Notre Dame

This panel aims to rediscover Alexander von Humboldt for an MLA audience attuned to questions of translation. Celebrated as “the real discoverer of South America” (Simon Bolívar), Humboldt must be reintroduced for our own time, a European identified with Latin America and a self-identified Americas booster.

Our roundtable previews the publication of Keywords in Disability Studies (ed. Rachel Adams, Benjamin Reiss, and David Serlin, NYU Press, 2015). title: In Search of Forgotten Women in Pre-1800 Iberia and the Americas
text: Program arranged by GEMELA: Grupo de Estudios sobre la Mujer en España y las Américas (pre-1800). Presiding: Emily C. Francomano, Georgetown Univ.
Speakers: Karen Douglas Alexander, Dallas Baptist Univ.; Sara Vicuna Guengerich, Texas Tech Univ.; Sacramento Rosello-Martinez, Syddansk Univ.
Respondent: Margaret Boyle, Bowdoin Coll.

Given that medieval and early modern women's histories so often remain untold and thus absent from cultural and scholarly sites of memory, this session will focus on women who have not yet received full attention by critics yet whose lives and works broke social, legal, and religious boundaries: writers, adventurers, travelers, ethnic "others," misfits, outlaws, and "outliers."

title: The Pleasure of the Postcolonial Text
text: Program arranged by the Division on Postcolonial Studies in Literature and Culture. Presiding: Anjali Prabhu, Wellesley Coll.
Speakers: Nicholas Mainey Brown, Univ. of Illinois, Chicago; Françoise Lionnet, Univ. of California, Los Angeles; Ato Quayson, Univ. of Toronto

Postcolonial literary studies have sometimes privileged theme or motif over the body of the text itself and the reader’s seduction by it. Panelists take up the challenge to engage the writerly pleasures of well-known postcolonial novels under the aegis of Barthes’s invitation to speak not “‘on’ such a text” but rather “‘in’ it."

title: Aesthetic Cosmopolitanism in African American Literary Traditions
text: A special session. Presiding: Gene Andrew Jarrett, Boston Univ.

Speakers: Adeleke Adeeko, Ohio State Univ., Columbus; Elizabeth McHenry, New York Univ.; Carla L. Peterson, Univ. of Maryland, College Park; Cherene Monique Sherrard-Johnson, Univ. of Wisconsin, Madison

Our roundtable examines cosmopolitan moments in African American literature from 1830 to 1940. How do we identify our texts as cosmopolitan—as both an ethic and an aesthetic concerned with form? How can we envision them as sites of memory in African American literary traditions that negotiate with literary histories beyond national, ethnic, and racial borders at different moments in time?

title: Performing the Queer Archive: Memory, Ephemera, and the Theories of José Esteban Muñoz
text: A special session. Presiding: Ramón H. Rivera-Servera, Northwestern Univ.

Speakers: Robin Bernstein, Harvard Univ.; Joshua Chambers-Letson, Northwestern Univ.; Jennifer Doyle, Univ. of California, Riverside; Brian Eugenio Herrera, Princeton Univ.; Jeanne Vaccaro, Univ. of Pennsylvania

This roundtable focuses on the performance studies scholar and queer theorist José E. Muñoz and his conceptualization and circulation of queer archives as practices of memory made relevant to the present in and through performance. It is especially concerned with Muñoz’s investments and theorizations of ephemera as queer evidence.

title: Return to In the Land of the Head Hunters: Silent Feature Film and the Negotiation of Memory in British Columbia
text: A special session. Presiding: Brad Evans, Rutgers Univ., New Brunswick

Speakers: Colin Browne, Simon Fraser Univ.; Dana Claxton, Univ. of British Columbia, Vancouver; Leigh Anne Duck, Univ. of Mississippi; Andy Everson, Courtenay, BC; Aaron Glass, Bard Graduate Center; Brian Hochman, Georgetown Univ.; Owen Underhill, Simon Fraser Univ.

A discussion of indigenous and nonindigenous negotiation of cultural memory in British Columbia, taking as its focus In the Land of the Head Hunters, a spectacular silent feature film, the product of Edward S. Curtis’s encounter and collaboration with the Kwakwaka’wakw (Kwakiutl) in 1914. Literary scholars, film historians, musicians, and indigenous artists reassess the film and its legacy.
For overview and abstracts, visit www.curtisfilm.rutgers.edu after 1 Jan.

title: Who Defines College Readiness? The Common Core State Standards and the Future of English Studies
text: Program arranged by the Office of the Executive Director. Presiding: Patricia Howell Michaelson, Univ. of Texas, Dallas; Donna L. Pasternak, Univ. of Wisconsin, Milwaukee

Speakers: Barbara L. Cambridge, National Council of Teachers of English; Elizabeth Gonsalves, Abington High School, MA; Kelly Mays, Univ. of Nevada, Las Vegas; Louann Reid, Colorado State Univ., Fort Collins; Catharine Roslyn Stimpson, New York Univ.

Stakeholders discuss the role of university faculty members in addressing the CCSS. How will the CCSS affect both literature and English education majors? Do the concepts of reading taught in the CCSS prepare students for college-level work? What is missing from the CCSS? How can we reach out to colleagues in secondary schools to support their work in preparing students for college?

title: Mentoring, Memory, Reinvention: A Session in Honor of Roberta Johnson
text: A special session. Presiding: Vicky Unruh, Univ. of Kansas

Speakers: Silvia Bermúdez, Univ. of California, Santa Barbara; Luis Cuesta, Univ. of Missouri, Columbia; Vanessa Marie Fernández, Duquesne Univ.; María Francisca Paredes Méndez, Western Washington Univ.; Jorge P. Pérez, Univ. of Kansas; Jill Robbins, Univ. of Texas, Austin; Carmen Sanjuan-Pastor, Scripps Coll.

In honor of the stellar mentoring career of Roberta Johnson, this roundtable examines mentoring as a cultural practice rooted in memory that also generates reinvention. In a range of scenarios, presenters address the challenges to mentoring posed by cultural, intellectual, and disciplinary change and the distinct role of mentoring in that change.

title: Why Chaucer Now?
text: Program arranged by the Division on Chaucer. Presiding: Emma E. Lipton, Univ. of Missouri, Columbia

Speakers: Jeffrey Jerome Cohen, George Washington Univ.; Frank Grady, Univ. of Missouri, St. Louis; Patricia Clare Ingham, Univ. of Indiana, Bloomington; Larry Scanlon, Rutgers Univ., New Brunswick; Nicole Nolan Sidhu, East Carolina Univ.

Why do new medieval paradigms often originate with Chaucer? Why make a single author so central to the Middle English presence at the MLA as opposed to, say, a Middle English globalisms division? Engaging recent shifts in paradigms, publications, curricula, and institutions, this roundtable addresses the question of Chaucer's relevance during the new millennium.

title: Subaltern Studies Redux
text: Program arranged by the Division on Postcolonial Studies in Literature and Culture. Presiding: Bishnupriya Ghosh, Univ. of California, Santa Barbara
Speakers: Aamir R. Mufti, Univ. of California, Los Angeles; Sangeeta Ray, Univ. of Maryland, College Park; Bruce W. Robbins, Columbia Univ.; Sudipta Sen, Univ. of California, Davis

The critical agon over a universal history of capital drove the subaltern studies project. In the light of the subaltern's subsequent traction across disciplines as the placeholder for an unreadable political agency uncapturable in orthodox accounts of revolutionary awakening, this panel reconsiders the multiple histories of capital at work in postcolonial literary and cultural studies today.

title: The Future of the Print Record
text: Program arranged by the MLA Office of Scholarly Communication. Presiding: Kathleen Fitzpatrick, MLA

Speakers: James Grossman, American Historical Assn.; Chuck Henry, Council on Library and Information Resources; Geneva Henry, George Washington Univ.; Deanna Marcum, Ithaka S–R; Andrew M. Stauffer, Univ. of Virginia

New technologies, changing approaches to research, and growing strains on library space and budgets are dramatically affecting prospects for future access to the print record of the nineteenth and twentieth centuries. This session focuses on the development of a framework for collaborative, productive decision making among faculty members and librarians in shaping the future of library collections.
For background materials, visit printrecord.commons.mla.org after 1 Dec.

title: Friday, 11:35 a.m.
Enhancing Research, Supporting the Researcher: ProQuest Literature Resources and ProQuest Flow
cal: Friday, 11:35–11:55 a.m., Exhibit Hall Theater, VCC West
text: Presented by ProQuest, booth 424

ProQuest is committed to enhancing the research process by providing tools and resources that facilitate and empower the researcher to make new connections and discoveries. Nicky Agate and John Pegum present some of ProQuest’s key resources for literary research, including the MLA International Bibliography and Literature Online, and demonstrate ProQuest Flow, a free cloud-based reference and full-text document manager.

title: Friday, 12:00 noon
Bibliography for the Twenty-First Century
text: Program arranged by the Discussion Group on Libraries and Research in Languages and Literatures and the Discussion Group on Bibliography and Textual Studies. Presiding: Dawn Childress, Penn State Univ. Libraries; Matt Cohen, Univ. of Texas, Austin
1. "An English Short Title Catalogue for the Twenty-First Century," Benjamin F. Pauley, Eastern Connecticut State Univ.; Carl Stahmer, Univ. of California, Santa Barbara
2. "Bibliographic Migration and Book Ecology: The SFU Lake District Rare Book Collection in the Twenty-First Century," Margaret Linley, Simon Fraser Univ.
3. "The Digital Antiquarian: Remediating Archival Impulses," Thomas Augst, New York Univ.; Molly Hardy, American Antiquarian Soc.
For abstracts and links, visit mlalibraries.commons.mla.org/2015-bibliography-for-the-21st-century.

title: Romanticism at Sea?
text: Program arranged by the Division on Comparative Studies in Romanticism and the Nineteenth Century. Presiding: Jan Mieszkowski, Reed Coll.
Speakers: Samuel E. Baker, Univ. of Texas, Austin; David L. Clark, McMaster Univ.; Talissa Ford, Temple Univ., Philadelphia; Brian McGrath, Clemson Univ.; Maureen Noelle McLane, New York Univ.

What are the key challenges facing the study of Romanticism? What are the most important changes taking place in the field, particularly insofar as it is understood in a comparative (transregional, transnational, transatlantic) framework?

title: Queer Counterarchives
text: Program arranged by the Division on Gay Studies in Language and Literature. Presiding: Christopher Looby, Univ. of California, Los Angeles

Speakers: Rustem Ertug Altinay, New York Univ.; Claudia Cabello-Hutt, Univ. of North Carolina, Greensboro; Margaret Galvan, Graduate Center, City Univ. of New York; Elizabeth Rosa Horan, Arizona State Univ.; Lynne Huffer, Emory Univ.; Thomas Van Camp, Portland State Univ.

Must a queer archive always be a counterarchive? If an archive is understood as always tinctured by the official and premised on a fantasy of grounding origin, must it be read queerly, resisted, or countered? This roundtable explores various unfamiliar queer counterarchives from different places (Turkey to Texas) and times (the Ottoman Empire to the early twentieth-century United States Southwest).

title: Unfinished "South Asian" Pasts
text: Program arranged by the Discussion Group on South Asian Languages and Literatures. Presiding: Chandrima Chakraborty, McMaster Univ.
Speakers: Atreyee Gohain, Ohio Univ., Athens; Maryse Jayasuriya, Univ. of Texas, El Paso; Shuchi Kapila, Grinnell Coll.; Rajender Kaur, William Paterson Univ.; Farah Moosa, McMaster Univ.

This roundtable explores the irruptions of multiple (national) pasts in the present in order to investigate why and how seemingly disparate historical traumas congeal in the popular imagination. Panelists reflect on the critical reworking of memories of historical events that continue to affect South Asia and its diaspora, together with the problem of how to represent and transmit them.

title: Interpreting J. M. Coetzee’s The Childhood of Jesus
text: A special session. Presiding: Elizabeth Anker, Cornell Univ.
1. "'We Don't Live under the Eye of God': The Dialectic of Abstraction," Timothy Bewes, Brown Univ.
2. "'What Is Value?': Coetzee's Mathematical Sublime," C. Namwali Serpell, Univ. of California, Berkeley
3. "Why We Love Coetzee: Postcolonial Studies and the Theological Politics of Critique," Elizabeth Anker

title: Memory, Palimpsests, and Indigenous Literatures
text: Program arranged by the Association for the Study of Literature and the Environment and the Association for the Study of American Indian Literatures. Presiding: Clare Echterling, Univ. of Kansas; Janis A. Johnson, Univ. of Idaho

Speakers: Creighton Brown, Univ. of Kansas; Lydia Heberling, San Diego State Univ.; Zach Horton, Univ. of California, Santa Barbara; Channette Romero, Univ. of Georgia; Brian J. Twenter, Univ. of South Dakota

This roundtable considers Indigenous literatures, environmental degradation, colonialism, and resistance. How might reading environments and sacred places as palimpsests expose histories modified and hidden by colonialism? Through its transnational ecocritical focus, this panel also considers the broader implications of postcolonial ecocriticism for Indigenous studies.

title: Horizons of Literary Food Studies: Genres, Materials, Methods
text: A special session. Presiding: Erica Fretwell, Univ. at Albany, State Univ. of New York

Speakers: Allison Carruth, Univ. of California, Los Angeles; Anne Cheng, Princeton Univ.; J. Michelle Coghlan, Univ. of Manchester; Amy Tigner, Univ. of Texas, Arlington; Kyla Wazana Tompkins, Pomona Coll.

This roundtable offers brief presentations by literary scholars with an interest in food studies. Each presenter uses a primary text to reflect on current methodologies for bringing food studies and literary studies together. Given the recent publication of many key books in this field, together we hope to think about future directions for the study of food and literature.

title: Open Hearing on Resolutions
text: Presiding: Members of the Delegate Assembly Organizing Committee

This meeting is open only to MLA members. During this open hearing, MLA members and delegates may discuss the regular resolutions that are on the Delegate Assembly's agenda. (For information on regular resolutions, i.e., those submitted by 1 Oct., visit www.mla.org/dameeting_agenda after 15 Dec.) MLA members may also submit emergency resolutions to the presider until the 1:00 p.m. submission deadline.

title: Teaching, Research, Service: A Close Reading
text: A special session. Presiding: Sidonie Ann Smith, Univ. of Michigan, Ann Arbor
Speakers: Leonard Cassuto, Fordham Univ.; Vanessa Ryan, Brown Univ.; David R. Shumway, Carnegie Mellon Univ.

A close reading of "teaching, research, service," the tricolon that is used throughout the profession to define the academic life. Members of this roundtable consider the triad—how it came about, what it means—and its constituent elements. Why do we use this grouping to describe our jobs, and what are its implications?

title: Memories of the Future: Collectivity and the Global South in Žižek, Jameson, and Spivak
text: A special session. Presiding: Henry Schwarz, Georgetown Univ.
Speakers: Sandeep Banerjee, McGill Univ.; Auritro Majumder, Syracuse Univ.; Supriya M. Nair, Tulane Univ.; Coilin Parsons, Georgetown Univ.; Judith Abrams Plotz, George Washington Univ.

This panel illuminates the relation between collectivity and the importance of memory in the recent work of three prominent materialist literary critics, Fredric Jameson, Slavoj Žižek, and Gayatri Chakravorty Spivak, and their relevance for the study of contemporary world literature. If the aesthetic is “purposelessness,” what is the utility of its memories and visions of utopia?

title: Negotiating History: Family as Site of Memory

2. "Digging Up the Past: Family and Truth in Josef Haslinger's Fiona und Ferdinand," Anna Souchuk, DePaul Univ.
3. "The Past in a Dialogue between the Generations: Tanja Dücker's Himmelskörper and Olaf Müller's Schlesisches Wetter," Teresa Sudenis, Univ. of Toronto
4. "'The Personal Is Political': Dysfunctional Families and Disrupted National Identity in Postwar and Postunification German Literature and Film," Steffen Kaupp, Duke Univ.
For abstracts, write to rcriser@unca.edu.

title: Journal Editing 101: An Introduction to the Role of Editor
text: Program arranged by the Council of Editors of Learned Journals. Presiding: Sol Miguel-Prendes, Wake Forest Univ.
Speakers: Michael E. Cornett, Duke Univ.; George D. Greenia, Coll. of William and Mary; Mihoko Suzuki, Univ. of Miami; Steven Tötösy de Zepetnek, Purdue Univ., West Lafayette
This roundtable is designed as an introduction to journal editing for aspiring and new editors. It offers practical advice on how to run a scholarly journal, either print or digital.

title: Barbara Newman's Medieval Crossover
text: Program arranged by the Division on French Medieval Language and Literature and the Division on Comparative Studies in Medieval Literature. Presiding: Catherine M. Jones, Univ. of Georgia
Speakers: Catherine Brown, Univ. of Michigan, Ann Arbor; Matilda Tomaryn Bruckner, Boston Coll.; Cary Howie, Cornell Univ.; Barbara Newman, Northwestern Univ.

Discussion of Barbara Newman's recent book Medieval Crossover: Reading the Secular against the Sacred. Newman's study explores the dialectical relation between the secular and the sacred in premodern literature. The book discusses a wide range of texts, including Arthurian romances, saints' lives, satirical works, and late medieval allegory.

title: In Your Skin
text: Program arranged by the Medieval and Renaissance Drama Society. Presiding: Mario Longtin, Univ. of Western Ontario

Speakers: Raul Ariza-Barile, Univ. of Texas, Austin; Robert L. A. Clark, Kansas State Univ.; Garrett P. J. Epp, Univ. of Alberta; Vicki Hamblin, Western Washington Univ.; John Nassichuk, Univ. of Western Ontario

How does an actor slip into the skin of the other? What are the techniques used to make the transformation effective for the audience? This roundtable explores the many challenges of interpreting (embodying) the other onstage: a young man playing a female saint, a Christian playing a representative of a different faith, a clerk playing a nobleman, or any actor playing a devil or an angel.

title: Region and Its (Dis)Contents
text: Program arranged by the Discussion Group on Southern Literature. Presiding: Katherine Renee Henninger, Louisiana State Univ., Baton Rouge
Speakers: Eric Gary Anderson, George Mason Univ.; Katharine A. Burnett, Fisk Univ.; Deborah Cohn, Indiana Univ., Bloomington; Roberto M. Dainotto, Duke Univ.; George Handley, Brigham Young Univ., UT

Participants assess the meaning, value, and limitations of region as a framework for literary and cultural studies. How have the meanings of region or the regional shifted over time and in contemporary literature or cultural discourse? What innovative connections does a regional framework enable, or how might region limit or preclude such connections? Is region necessary?

title: What Is the Role of the Critical Edition in the Digital Age?
text: Program arranged by the MLA Committee on Scholarly Editions and the Society for Textual Scholarship. Presiding: John Young, Marshall Univ.

Speakers: Benjamin Albritton, Stanford Univ.; William Leake Andrews, Univ. of North Carolina, Chapel Hill; Neil Fraistat, Univ. of Maryland, College Park; Andrew Scott Galloway, Cornell Univ.; Kenneth M. Price, Univ. of Nebraska, Lincoln

Editing protocols date from the analog age. Digital editions continue to follow analog protocols. Textual scholars—and textual scholarship—can profit from discussion of digital technology's contribution to editing. Panelists, textual scholars with experience in both analog and digital editing technologies, discuss and suggest further exploration.

Participants in this roundtable discussion illustrate several of the career paths that humanists can and do pursue upon completion of their degrees. title: Friday, 3:30 p.m.

text: A forum. Presiding: Steven J. Meyer, Washington Univ. in St. Louis
Speakers: James J. Bono, Univ. at Buffalo, State Univ. of New York; Bruce Clarke, Texas Tech Univ.; N. Katherine Hayles, Duke Univ.; Isabelle Stengers, Free Univ. of Brussels

Science studies and literature and science have constituted two of the most exciting arenas for academic investigation in recent decades. This forum and its linked sessions examine the dynamic interplay between the two interfields. The idea is to introduce literature and science in all its heterogeneity and to suggest further directions such investigation may take.
For linked sessions, see meetings 455 and 628. For a description of the forum, visit english.artsci.wustl.edu/litsci after 1 Nov.

A discussion of the evolving relation between translation and the MLA, five years after Catherine Porter’s presidential theme, The Tasks of Translation in the Global Context. Perspectives on the place of translation studies, translation theory, and literary translation in academia. Presentations on current research, recent publications and developments in the field, and challenges and possible actions for the future.

title: A New Kind of Work: Articulating and Evaluating Excellence in Digital Scholarship
text: Program arranged by the MLA Office of Scholarly Communication. Presiding: Victoria E. Szabo, Duke Univ.
Speakers: Cheryl E. Ball, West Virginia Univ., Morgantown; David F. Bell, Duke Univ.; Alison Booth, Univ. of Virginia; Raymond G. Siemens, Univ. of Victoria; Julie Sykes, Univ. of Oregon

With the proliferation of scholarly practices broadly defined as “digital” comes the challenge of evaluating such work within existing disciplinary standards and structures. How are faculty members, chairs, and administrators negotiating this challenge? What constitutes excellence for different types of projects? How do we know it, define it, refine it, and promote it in our institutions?
For background material, visit evaluatingdigitalscholarship.commons.mla.org/ after 1 Dec.

title: Protecting Campus Freedoms: Speech, Assembly, Disruption

When considering academic freedom, what counts as protected speech, free assembly, or disruption? Beginning with ethics (Hogan) and law (Post), speakers will turn to political considerations (Michaels), institutional issues such as academic freedom and contingent labor (Swidler), then extramural social concerns exemplified by the Occupy movement (Scott).

Respondent: Joseph North, Columbia Univ.

Historicist-contextualist criticism dominates academic writing, but that genre is not the only one at the critic’s disposal. Editors and practitioners of varied forms of critical writing gather to assess the present and future of criticism in its full panoply of modes. Our goal is to show the strength of intellectual writing and suggest how the profession—and the culture—can foster strong criticism.

This roundtable will present a variety of radical perspectives on current controversies over academic boycotts and academic freedom. Given the recent and continuing debates—not least within the MLA—surrounding the November 2013 decision by the American Studies Association to support the academic boycott of Israeli universities, this session will be timely.

title: Nineteenth-Century by Twenty-First-Century Poetic Crossings
text: Program arranged by the Division on Nineteenth-Century American Literature. Presiding: Meredith L. McGill, Rutgers Univ., New Brunswick
Speakers: Radiclani Clytus, Brown Univ.; Virginia Jackson, Univ. of California, Irvine; Amaud Jamaul Johnson, Univ. of Wisconsin, Madison; Evie Shockley, Rutgers Univ., New Brunswick

There has been a resurgence of interest among contemporary poets in nineteenth-century American poetry. This panel brings together poets and critics to explore the generative power and long reach of nineteenth-century poems and the challenge contemporary poetry poses to literary critics to rethink the history of American poetry.

title: NAFTA, Neoliberalism, and Twenty-First-Century Mexican Narratives
text: Program arranged by the Discussion Group on Mexican Cultural and Literary Studies. Presiding: Juan Carlos Ramírez-Pimienta, San Diego State Univ.

Speakers: Hilda Chacón, Nazareth Coll. of Rochester; Ignacio Corona, Ohio State Univ., Columbus; Max Parra, Univ. of California, San Diego; Ignacio Sanchez-Prado, Washington Univ. in St. Louis; Anne Stachura, Univ. of Texas–Pan American; Samuel Steinberg, Univ. of Southern California

After two decades of the implementation of NAFTA and its inherent embrace of neoliberal policies, Mexico is a very different country from the one conceived during its postrevolution. Panelists discuss how the country is being imagined and narrated in the twenty-first century and what the implications of these paradigmatic changes are for Mexican studies.

title: The MLA and Its Data: Remix, Reuse, and Research
text: Program arranged by the MLA Committee on Information Technology. Presiding: Marguerite Helen Helmers, Univ. of Wisconsin, Oshkosh

Speakers: Brian Croxall, Emory Univ.; Jonathan Goodwin, Univ. of Louisiana, Lafayette; David Laurence, MLA; Ernesto Priego, City Univ. London; Lisa Marie Rhody, George Mason Univ.; Christopher Zarate, MLA

As an organization, the MLA produces many kinds of data: the bibliography, the Job Information List, and its publications. We scholars produce data "about" the MLA as well, through social media connected to the annual convention. This panel presents work on what we can learn about the professions of language and literature when we analyze the data collectively produced by the MLA and its members.
For abstracts, visit infotech.commons.mla.org/ after 15 Dec.

title: Restructuring Foreign Language Departments Brings National Recognition
text: Program arranged by the American Council on the Teaching of Foreign Languages and the American Association of Teachers of German. Presiding: Martha Abbott, American Council on the Teaching of Foreign Languages
Speakers: Keith Cothrun, American Assn. of Teachers of German; Peter Höyng, Emory Univ.; Barbara K. Kosta, Univ. of Arizona; Elvira Swender, American Council on the Teaching of Foreign Languages

Foreign language departments are meeting the needs of today's students by revising curricula, setting language proficiency targets, and incorporating courses that focus on language for special purposes. These innovations have brought them national recognition from programs offered by AATG and ACTFL.
For program descriptions and summary of speaker comments, visit www.actfl.org.

title: Friday, 6:45 p.m.
The Presidential Address
text: Presiding: Rosemary G. Feal, MLA
1. Welcome, Larry Grant, Musqueam Nation
2. Report of the Executive Director, Rosemary G. Feal

3. The Presidential Address, Margaret W. Ferguson, Univ. of California, Davis, MLA President. Ferguson will explore strategies of negotiation (involving challenge, persuasion, translation, interpretation, performance of real or feigned hope and expressing awareness of possible failure) among several contested sites of memory in today's academy. These include Vancouver itself, the humanities classroom today and in the past, and the MLA, as an organization whose members have competing memories about its mission.
Reception immediately following.

A Screening of The Penelope Project
text: Presiding: E. Ann Kaplan, Stony Brook Univ., State Univ. of New York
Speaker: Anne Basting, Univ. of Wisconsin, Milwaukee

The Penelope Project, a nonfiction film directed by Brad Lichtenstein, documents a collaboration led by Anne Basting, playwright and scholar in creativity and aging studies; Michael Rohd and the Sojourn Theatre; and Luther Manor, a care facility in Milwaukee. Residents, artists, and students engaged a care community in exploring Penelope's "creative waiting" and the later years of life.

title: Unsociable Feelings: Egoism, Cynicism, Intolerance, Indifference, Stoicism, Disgust
text: Program arranged by the Division on Late-Eighteenth-Century English Literature. Presiding: Sandra Macpherson, Ohio State Univ., Columbus

Speakers: Alison Conway, Univ. of Western Ontario; Michael Edson, Univ. of Wyoming; John Owen Havard, Binghamton Univ., State Univ. of New York; Alex Hernandez, Univ. of Toronto; Wendy Lee, New York Univ.; Jacob Risinger, Ohio State Univ., Columbus

A roundtable on the affective states overshadowed when eighteenth-century studies focuses on sympathetic exchange. Each of the speakers derives specific affects from specific forms (novel, essay, poetry, drama), tying affect theory more firmly to literary history than it has been before. The panel locates within the age of sociability a negativity opening onto alternate modes of sociality.

title: The Global Novel: Theories, Forms, Histories, Controversies
text: Program arranged by the Division on Twentieth-Century English Literature. Presiding: Priya Joshi, Temple Univ., Philadelphia
Speakers: Sarah Brouillette, Carleton Univ.; Bruce W. Robbins, Columbia Univ.; Mariano Siskind, Harvard Univ.; Aarthi Vadde, Duke Univ.; Mukoma Wa Ngugi, Cornell Univ.

This roundtable gathers diverse approaches to the global novel as an emergent genre of contemporary fiction, a culmination of the novel’s long history of transnational circulation and analysis, and a flashpoint for world literature and globalization debates.

title: Worldly Women: Cosmopolitanism and Transnational Female Performance in Early Modern Europe
text: Program arranged by the Society for the Study of Early Modern Women. Presiding: Pamela Allen Brown, Univ. of Connecticut, Stamford; Melinda J. Gough, McMaster Univ.
Speakers: Caroline Bicks, Boston Coll.; Perry J. Gethner, Oklahoma State Univ., Stillwater; Clare McManus, Univ. of Roehampton; Stephen Orgel, Stanford Univ.; Amy Tigner, Univ. of Texas, Arlington

This roundtable focuses on professional actresses, courtesans, and female aristocrats from Spain, Italy, France, and England, glamorous and sophisticated women who became early icons of cosmopolitanism. Discussion will center on transcultural players who circulated novel theatrical materials and forms and their representations in art, travel and diplomatic accounts, and plays.

title: Remembering Williams, Williams Remembering
text: Program arranged by the William Carlos Williams Society. Presiding: Margaret Konkol, Georgia Inst. of Tech.

Speakers: Jennifer Chang, George Washington Univ.; Jim Cocola, Worcester Polytechnic Inst.; Alan Golding, Univ. of Louisville; Nate Mickelson, Guttman Community Coll., City Univ. of New York; Christopher Patrick Miller, Univ. of California, Berkeley; Shawna Ross, Arizona State Univ. Polytechnic

Aspects of memory in relation to William Carlos Williams's poetry and writing, with a focus on details such as forgotten poems, forgetfulness and memory in Williams, invention and memory in Spring and All, urban poetics in Paterson, memory and image in Journey to Love, and medical ethics in Williams's short stories.

title: Ideology and the ISA (Ideological State Apparatus) Today: On Althusser's On the Reproduction of Capitalism
text: Program arranged by the Marxist Literary Group. Presiding: Caren Irr, Brandeis Univ.

Speakers: Nicholas Mainey Brown, Univ. of Illinois, Chicago; Carolyn Lesjak, Simon Fraser Univ.; Oded Nir, Ohio State Univ., Columbus; Imre Szeman, Univ. of Alberta; Phillip Edward Wegner, Univ. of Florida

Participants discuss Althusser's On the Reproduction of Capitalism, an important 1968-era work, left unfinished at his death, published in English for the first time by Verso in February 2014. Given recent assertions that ideology critique is superfluous in a world of surfaces, how salient is Althusser's concept of ideology for contemporary critical discussions?

title: Disrupting the Digital Humanities
text: A special session. Presiding: Sean Michael Morris, Hybrid Pedagogy

Speakers: Fiona Barnett, Duke Univ.; Kathi Inman Berens, Univ. of Southern California; Dorothy Kim, Vassar Coll.; Adeline Koh, Richard Stockton Coll. of New Jersey; Elika Ortega Guzman, Univ. of Western Ontario; Roopika Risam, Salem State Univ.; Jesse Stommel, Univ. of Wisconsin, Madison

All too often, defining a discipline becomes more an exercise of exclusion than inclusion. This roundtable rethinks how we map disciplinary terrain by directly confronting the gatekeeping impulse of so many academic disciplines. Participants investigate the edges and open the digital humanities more fully to its fringes and outliers.
For papers, visit www.disruptingdh.com after 18 Nov.

title: Transatlantic Milton
text: A special session. Presiding: Joanna Picciotto, Univ. of California, Berkeley
Speakers: Angelica Alicia Duran, Purdue Univ., West Lafayette; Marissa Nicosia, Univ. of Pennsylvania; Gillian Osborne, Univ. of California, Berkeley; Joanna Picciotto; Edward Simon, Lehigh Univ.

As self-styled Puritan prophet, champion of liberty and toleration, and creator of a "new-modeled" Eden in which still-available historical potentials might be glimpsed, John Milton has long held a privileged place in genealogies of liberalism, modernity, and American exceptionalism. Participants focus on American "rewritings" of Milton.

title: The Uses of AIME for Literary Inquiry
text: A linked session arranged in conjunction with the forum Literature and Science Studies. Presiding: Bruce Clarke, Texas Tech Univ.
1. "Starting from Part One: Providers of Direction, Words of Love (AIME)," Steven J. Meyer, Washington Univ. in St. Louis
2. "Starting from Part Two: Attachment, Enchantment, Fiction," Rita Felski, Univ. of Virginia
3. "Starting from Part Three: The Chaos of the Scripts," Heather K. Love, Univ. of Pennsylvania

Examination of current work by the anthropologist and sociologist of science Bruno Latour as it pertains to literary studies. "AIME" refers both to An Inquiry into Modes of Existence: An Anthropology of the Moderns (2013) and to modesofexistence.org, a collaborative augmented platform, with respect to which the volume functions as a research report. The speakers introduce the report's three parts.
For a description of the forum, visit english.artsci.wustl.edu/litsci after 1 Nov.

title: Carmen Martín Gaite in the Twenty-First Century: What Defines Her Legacy?
text: A special session. Presiding: Joan L. Brown, Univ. of Delaware, Newark

Speakers: Isabel Estrada, City Coll., City Univ. of New York; David Thatcher Gies, Univ. of Virginia; María Luisa Guardiola, Swarthmore Coll.; David Keith Herzberger, Univ. of California, Riverside; Randolph D. Pope, Univ. of Virginia; Alexandra Saum-Pascual, Univ. of California, Berkeley; José Teruel, Universidad Autónoma de Madrid

Carmen Martín Gaite was a complex figure whose works transformed literary and cultural fields. The goal of this session is to define the Martín Gaite canon, fifteen years after her passing. Panelists and audience members will work together to characterize Martín Gaite’s enduring contributions to Spanish literature and explain why the author has such strong appeal today.

title: Modernism, Feminism, and Disability
text: Program arranged by the Modernist Studies Association. Presiding: Jessica Berman, Univ. of Maryland Baltimore County

Speakers: Rachel Adams, Columbia Univ.; Madelyn Detloff, Miami Univ., Oxford; Maren T. Linett, Purdue Univ., West Lafayette; Janet W. Lyon, Penn State Univ., University Park; Joseph Valente, Univ. at Buffalo, State Univ. of New York

This roundtable explores the convergences of modernism, feminism, and disability, focusing on how feminist disability studies revises our approaches to modernist form, shifts our conceptions of gender in modernism, and generates new nonnormative models for reading modernist texts.

title: Gender and the Archives
text: A special session. Presiding: Jacqueline D. Wernimont, Scripps Coll.

Speakers: Jessica J. Beard, Univ. of California, Santa Cruz; Laura Goldblatt, Univ. of Virginia; Anne Kingsley, Northeastern Univ.; Judith Scholes, Univ. of British Columbia, Vancouver; Nicole Sierra, Univ. of Oxford, Jesus Coll.

Recognizing that the archive is always a problematic foundation of historical record, this roundtable examines how gender matters there—that is, how gender constructs and gendered bodies or materials impact the collection, preservation, or existence of archives. Discussion covers digital archives, unarchived bodies, misidentifications, curation, and counterarchives.

title: Reading, Complexity, and the Common Core
text: Program arranged by the MLA Executive Council. Presiding: Margaret W. Ferguson, Univ. of California, Davis
1. "The Common Core: Are Forensics Enough?" David Steiner, Hunter Coll., City Univ. of New York
2. "The Common Core and the Evasion of Curriculum," John David Guillory, New York Univ.
3. "The Many Colors of Complexity," Michael Holquist, Yale Univ.

As the Common Core State Standards are about to be implemented nationwide, several aspects of the guidelines remain controversial. Framers of the new program have insisted they are aware improvements might be made, and they have asked for broader discussion. In the materials devoted to the English language arts standards in the Common Core, no subject is addressed at greater length than "complexity," particularly as it relates to reading. This session explores that concept from a range of perspectives and aims to foster discussion among secondary school and college teachers in the MLA about strengths and weaknesses in the Common Core as it goes forward.

title: What Orgasmology Teaches Us about Sex: A Roundtable with Annamarie Jagose
text: A special session. Presiding: Kadji Amin, Stony Brook Univ., State Univ. of New York
Speakers: Steven Angelides, La Trobe Univ.; Jane Gallop, Univ. of Wisconsin, Milwaukee; Annamarie Jagose, Univ. of Sydney; Valerie J. Traub, Univ. of Michigan, Ann Arbor; Robyn Wiegman, Duke Univ.

This roundtable uses Annamarie Jagose’s Orgasmology to explore the turn toward the study of sex practices in the critical and queer humanities. Working as a collaborative discussion, the session seconds Jagose’s sense that orgasm is “good to think with” by elaborating her project’s impact on current theories of affect, subjectivity, normativity, and the limits of interpretation itself.

title: Remembering—and Not Forgetting—Wanda Coleman
text: A special session. Presiding: Jennifer Denise Ryan, State Univ. of New York, Buffalo State Coll.
Speakers: Shanna Greene Benjamin, Grinnell Coll.; Malin Pereira, Univ. of North Carolina, Charlotte; Austin Straus, independent scholar

The Los Angeles poet Wanda Coleman has received relatively little critical recognition. Our conversation centers on the innovative aspects of Coleman’s poetry and prose in order to memorialize her work and to motivate new assessments of her writing. We offer four approaches to reading and understanding her work that incorporate her perspectives on American society and the academy.
For abstracts, write to ryanjd@buffalostate.edu after 10 Dec.

Each facilitator proposes an open-ended question related to the idea jam topic. Participants then work with the facilitator whose question most intrigues them to brainstorm ideas, concerns, etc.

This panel explores steps graduate programs can take to increase transparency and preparation for a full spectrum of possible career choices for their students. The panelists represent programs that are working to make career development integral to the experience of current graduate students and develop capacities to track and report the occupational outcomes of their graduates.

Panelists discuss how discourse in the public sphere is gendered, both in terms of overall representation and in the assumptions and expectations inherent in its framing, and consider interaction with different publics inside and outside institutions, professional self-representation, news and feature journalism, op-ed writing, radio and TV appearances, book reviewing, and social media.

title: Multimedia Realisms
text: A special session. Presiding: Phillip Maciak, Louisiana State Univ., Baton Rouge; Eden Osucha, Bates Coll.

This roundtable fosters an interdisciplinary exchange about the return to realism in film and literary theory. Instead of creating a streamlined metanarrative of twentieth-century realism, the participants hope to conceive of realism as a malleable tool for putting diverse texts in conversation rather than keeping them apart.

title: Saturday, 1:20 p.m.
Using Juxta Editions to Create Digital Scholarly Editions
cal: Saturday, 1:20–1:40 p.m., Exhibit Hall Theater, VCC West
text: Presented by Juxta Editions, booth 504

Nick Laiacona, president, Performant Software Solutions, LLC, presents Juxta Editions, a professional editing suite for the creation of digital scholarly editions. Scholarly editors, historians, archivists, and academic librarians are increasingly using the Internet to share primary source material with one another and the public. However, the set of technologies required to deliver a state-of-the-art scholarly edition remains dauntingly expensive and difficult to master. Using Juxta, you can transcribe, annotate, collate, and publish to the Internet a work or collection of related writings. The session includes a demonstration of Juxta Editions.

title: A Creative Conversation with Roy Miki and Smaro Kamboureli

Beginning with presentations of examples from nineteenth-century American literary studies, participants discuss how digital tools have answered and can continue to answer foregrounded literary and literary historical questions. This approach is presented in contrast to those that prioritize the collection and presentation of new kinds of textual information.

title: The Scholar-Parent
text: Program arranged by the MLA Committee on Disability Issues in the Profession. Presiding: Rachel Adams, Columbia Univ.

Speakers: Amanda Apgar, Univ. of California, Los Angeles; Chris Gabbard, Univ. of North Florida; Paola Gemme, Arkansas Tech Univ.; Janet W. Lyon, Penn State Univ., University Park; Joseph Valente, Univ. at Buffalo, State Univ. of New York

This session explores how academic life can enhance and complicate the experience of raising a child with special needs. Understanding disabled identity as a form of embodied knowledge, speakers use their experiences to theorize the distinctive contribution parents make to disability studies, a resource for rethinking how we theorize autonomy, rights, citizenship, and personhood.

title: Geoffrey Hartman: His Thinking and Influence
text: A special session. Presiding: Kevis Goodman, Univ. of California, Berkeley

Speakers: Marshall J. Brown, Univ. of Washington, Seattle; Cathy Caruth, Cornell Univ.; Frances Ferguson, Univ. of Chicago; Anne-Lise François, Univ. of California, Berkeley; Paul Harrison Fry, Yale Univ.; Marc Redfield, Brown Univ.; David E. Simpson, Univ. of California, Davis

A roundtable on Geoffrey Hartman’s sixty-year career and commitment to negotiating sites of memory from Romanticism to the present. Panelists discuss the impact of Hartman’s work on a wide range of fields: British and European Romanticism, the history of literary criticism and critical theory, memory studies, media studies, trauma theory, and Holocaust testimony and remembrance.

title: Unfinished Business
text: Program arranged by the American Literature Section. Presiding: Lloyd P. Pratt, Univ. of Oxford
Speakers: Aimee Bahng, Dartmouth Coll.; Nicole Brittingham Furlonge, Princeton Day School; Yogita Goyal, Univ. of California, Los Angeles; Emily Lordi, Univ. of Massachusetts, Amherst

Analogy, exclusion, strategy, silence. Each term recalls the political interventionist vocabulary of the 1960s–80s. But reaction against such movements, as in surface reading, big data, and cognitivism, warrants careful consideration of what permits discarding one critical lexicon in favor of another. The roundtable revisits these key concepts to consider their continued saliency to the field.
For abstracts, write to lloydpratt@gmail.com after 1 Dec.

title: Saturday, 3:30 p.m.
Desire for Narrative in Law and Literature
text: A special session. Presiding: Derek Miller, Harvard Univ.; Robin Wharton, Georgia State Univ.

Speakers: Michael Bachmann, Johannes Gutenberg–Universität Mainz; Andrew Bricker, McGill Univ.; Kelly Rich, Univ. of Pennsylvania; Simon Stern, Univ. of Toronto; Christopher Warren, Carnegie Mellon Univ.; Amanda Waugh, Univ. of Massachusetts, Amherst

Hayden White argues, “Where there is no rule of law, there can be neither a subject nor the kind of event which lends itself to narrative representation.” This roundtable surveys new approaches to law and narrative, interrogating the poetics of legal texts, the documentary and memorial imperatives of trauma narratives, and the role of the state in postcolonial and international jurisprudence.

title: Claiming West Asia: How to Think as a Continentalist
text: Program arranged by the Discussion Group on West Asian Languages and Literatures and the Division on Comparative Studies in Twentieth-Century Literature. Presiding: Stephen Sheehi, Coll. of William and Mary
Speakers: Ali Behdad, Univ. of California, Los Angeles; Nergis Ertürk, Penn State Univ., University Park; Seteney Shami, Social Science Research Council; Veli N. Yashin, Columbia Univ.
Respondent: Gayatri Chakravorty Spivak, Columbia Univ.

This roundtable examines what it means to claim West Asia as a comparative literary space. It explores how the term West Asia supplements other regional categories (the Near East and Eurasia) and the practice of comparatism at large. Other topics to be discussed include critical regionalism; continentalism; the legacies of European, Russian, and Soviet Orientalisms; and literary communisms.

title: Democracy in American Literary and Cultural Studies: Past, Present, and Future
text: A special session. Presiding: Gregory Laski, United States Air Force Acad.

Speakers: Christopher D. Castiglia, Penn State Univ., University Park; Russ Castronovo, Univ. of Wisconsin, Madison; D. Berton Emerson, California State Polytechnic Univ., Pomona; Jennifer Greiman, Univ. at Albany, State Univ. of New York; Koritha Mitchell, Ohio State Univ., Columbus; Dana D. Nelson, Vanderbilt Univ.; Derrick R. Spires, Univ. of Illinois, Urbana

Democracy has long been a key concern for United States literary and cultural studies. In the last two decades alone, critics have explored this political form in relation to death, deliberation, interiority, spectacle, and spectrality. This roundtable brings together a diverse group of scholars to reflect on recent theories and to suggest directions for future work.
For position statements, panelist biographies, and information about the roundtable format, visit democracy2015.commons.mla.org/ after 15 Dec.

This roundtable draws (renewed) attention to the nexus of linguistics and literary scholarship, identifies and critically negotiates current trends in literary linguistics, and points to possible future agendas for this field. title: Making Dada History
text: Program arranged by the Association for the Study of Dada and Surrealism. Presiding: Nicola Behrmann, Rutgers Univ., New Brunswick

Speakers: Jordan Amirkhani, Univ. of Kent; Shannon Connelly, Rutgers Univ., New Brunswick; Annabelle Goergen-Lammers, Hamburger Kunsthalle; Marius Hentea, Univ. of Ghent; Anna Horakova, Cornell Univ.; Timothy Shipe, Univ. of Iowa; Roger van Wyk, Cape Town, South Africa

This roundtable considers the historiographical and autobiographical production of Dada's history and of Dadaism as an “art movement." The memoirs, chronologies, diaries, letters, and manifestos of the Dada members form the basis for work by subsequent historians, archivists, and curators. In what ways do Dadaists control the definition of Dada? What is at stake in such definitions?

title: Lydia Millet
text: A special session. Presiding: Samuel Cohen, Univ. of Missouri, Columbia

Speakers: Margaret Hunt Gram, American Acad. of Arts and Sciences; Daniel Grausam, Durham Univ.; Rachel Greenwald Smith, Saint Louis Univ.; Jenny Howell, Univ. of Texas, Austin; Lee Konstantinou, Univ. of Maryland, College Park; Lisa Siraganian, Southern Methodist Univ.; Molly Wallace, Queen's Univ.

This roundtable examines the work of Lydia Millet, one of a very few contemporary writers poised to enter the canon. The panelists—scholars working on contemporary literature and culture—explore Millet’s work’s aesthetic, historical, environmental, and political aspects and also implicitly and sometimes explicitly make the case for Millet’s importance.

title: Science Fiction and Science Studies: The Example of Isabelle Stengers
text: A linked session arranged in conjunction with the forum Literature and Science Studies. Presiding: James J. Bono, Univ. at Buffalo, State Univ. of New York

4. "Stengers on Whitehead and Stengers on Science Fiction," Nicholas Gaskill, Rutgers Univ., New Brunswick
Respondent: Isabelle Stengers, Free Univ. of Brussels

This session examines how science fiction has functioned in literature and science as a model area of inquiry in the light of a recent essay by Isabelle Stengers concerning science fiction's role in her own distinctive admixture of science studies and philosophy of science. The speakers supply differing, complementary contexts for the essay, and Stengers then responds to their remarks.
For a description of the forum, visit english.artsci.wustl.edu/litsci after 1 Nov.

text: A special session. Presiding: Leila Mansouri, Univ. of California, Berkeley

Within the neoliberal university, creative writers and scholars often seem to be pitted against each other. This roundtable seeks to address the professional and institutional cultures that create such conflict. A range of authors and scholars discuss how programs might collaborate more effectively. How can we better foster literary culture in “the program era”?

A discussion about the relations between Wallace Stevens and his great Romantic precursor, Walt Whitman. What traces of Whitman's language and rhythms are there in Stevens's poetry? Are there overlapping concerns in their poetics, as expressed in prose and in poetry? How do we assess their places as distinctive American poets?

title: Saturday, 7:00 p.m.
Organizational Meeting for LLC Latina and Latino
Kurt Schwitters's Ursonate
text: Speaker: Christopher Butterfield, Univ. of Victoria

Kurt Schwitters's Ursonate (or Sonate in Urlauten ["Sonata in Primordial Sounds"]), written between 1922 and 1932, is regarded as the greatest sound poem of the twentieth century. The Canadian composer Christopher Butterfield will reprise his acclaimed interpretation of the Ursonate.

title: A Creative Conversation with the Canadian Poet JonArno Lawson
text: Presiding: Craig Svonkin, Metropolitan State Univ.; Joseph Terry Thomas, Jr., San Diego State Univ.
Speaker: JonArno Lawson, Toronto, ON

A creative conversation about avant-garde children’s poetry, Canadian poetry, and Canadian children’s poetry with the award-winning poet JonArno Lawson. Lawson is a three-time winner of the Lion and the Unicorn Award for Excellence in North American Poetry.

title: Antebellum Print Culture and the Digital Archive
text: Program arranged by the American Literature Section. Presiding: Ryan Cordell, Northeastern Univ.

Respondent: Meredith L. McGill, Rutgers Univ., New Brunswick

The widespread digitizing of virtually all nineteenth-century books, periodicals, and newspapers has created new online access to previously obscure materials. This panel assesses how digital technologies are facilitating new ways of doing research as well as promoting broader conceptions of "literature," the publishing world, and the circulation (and reprinting) of texts.

Twenty years after the publication of Nobody’s Story, this roundtable takes Catherine Gallagher’s pathbreaking scholarship on the rise of fictionality as a starting point for discussing current approaches to the fictive, the virtual, and the counterfactual as categories of experience.

title: Approaching The Peripheral: First Responses to William Gibson’s New Novel
text: A special session. Presiding: Brian Croxall, Emory Univ.

Speakers: Paul Benzon, Temple Univ., Philadelphia; Amy J. Elias, Univ. of Tennessee, Knoxville; Kathleen Fitzpatrick, MLA; Matthew Kirschenbaum, Univ. of Maryland, College Park; Lee Konstantinou, Univ. of Maryland, College Park; Andrew Pilsch, Arizona State Univ. Polytechnic; Zach Whalen, Univ. of Mary Washington

Fall 2014 saw the publication of The Peripheral, a novel by William Gibson. Turning his attention again to tomorrow, the author imagines the future of games, technology, and warfare and their effects on bodies, economies, and families. Scholars of contemporary literature present a range of approaches and share their early reactions, impressions, and suggestions for interpreting this new text.

title: Weird Fiction, Weird Methods
text: A special session. Presiding: Alison Sperling, Univ. of Wisconsin, Milwaukee

Speakers: S. T. Joshi, independent scholar; Eileen Joy, Univ. of California, Santa Barbara; Kate Marshall, Univ. of Notre Dame; Alison Sperling; Matthew A. Taylor, Univ. of North Carolina, Chapel Hill

This roundtable considers "the weird" as a literary genre or aesthetic and as a theoretical mode of inquiry. The weird is a mode that links literary movements past and present and has now pervasively intruded into current and critical debates that serve to trouble human beings’ place in a world much vaster than what can be gleaned from individual human accounts of experience.

title: Victorian Travelers and the Afterlives of Cultural Memory

Speakers: Samantha Burton, Univ. of Southern California; Lindsay Dearinger, Louisiana State Univ., Baton Rouge; Margaret Linley, Simon Fraser Univ.; Alex L. Milsom, Univ. of California, Los Angeles; Sarah Winter, Univ. of Connecticut, Storrs

How do travelers—pleasure tourists, colonial subjects, philanthropists—define themselves as/against the foreign and variously uphold or rewrite cultural narratives of places or peoples? The session includes brief synopses, followed by extended discussion among panelists and attendees to theorize the impact of cultural memory.
For abstracts, pre- and postconvention discussion, presentations, and discussion questions, visit victoriantravelers.commons.mla.org/.

text: Program arranged by the Discussion Group on Catalan Language and Literature and the Discussion Group on Romanian Studies. Presiding: Anton Pujol, Univ. of North Carolina, Charlotte
Speakers: Francesco Ardolino, Univ. of Barcelona; Maria-Sabina Draga Alexandru, Univ. of Bucharest; Meritxell Joan Rodríguez, Univ. of Barcelona; Mary Ann Newman, New York Univ.

This roundtable engages a variety of perspectives and focuses on aspects of translations from Catalan literature into other European languages, with the general intention to investigate the model of Catalan cultural promotion in the configuration of a European metaidentity and European Union cultural exchange.
For abstracts, write to sabina.draga@americanstudies.ro after 15 Dec.

title: Elena Poniatowska: Five Decades of Critical Inquiry
text: Program arranged by the Discussion Group on Mexican Cultural and Literary Studies. Presiding: Beth Ellen Jörgensen, Univ. of Rochester
Speakers: Linda Egan, Univ. of California, Davis; Emily Hind, Univ. of Florida; Beth Ellen Jörgensen; Alicia Rita Rueda-Acedo, Univ. of Texas, Arlington; Cynthia Steele, Univ. of Washington, Seattle

Poniatowska's works have inspired diverse approaches to literary theory and criticism, including approaches to testimonio, journalism, writing by women, and ethical imperatives in literature. We trace the trajectory of critical discourse on her work, how it tracks established trends in literary studies, and how it introduces new questions into literary debates in the United States and Mexico since the 1960s.

text: A special session. Presiding: Kimberley R. D. McLean-Fiander, Univ. of Victoria

Respondent: Janelle A. Jenstad, Univ. of Victoria

This roundtable explores the mobilization of digital humanities (DH) projects to promote research-based learning (RBL). Participants in The Map of Early Modern London’s pedagogical partnership share their experience with, and posit general applications for, this modified crowd-sourced guest editorship that benefits instructors, helps students acquire digital research skills, and builds DH projects.
For teaching materials, visit mapoflondon.uvic.ca/teaching.htm after 31 Dec.

title: Ignite Talk: Envisioning the Energy Humanities, Narrating Energy Pasts and Futures
text: Program arranged by the Marxist Literary Group. Presiding: Clint Burnham, Simon Fraser Univ.

Speakers: Brent Bellamy, Univ. of Alberta; Jeff Diamanti, Univ. of Alberta; Adam Dickinson, Brock Univ.; Peter James Hitchcock, Baruch Coll., City Univ. of New York; Stephanie LeMenager, Univ. of Oregon; Jennifer A. Wenzel, Columbia Univ.

This roundtable outlines possible and forgotten trajectories for the study of energy in the humanities. The project of the energy humanities introduces a social-materialist standpoint by wedding the story of energy to literary theory and history.

title: Geographies of Memory in Nineteenth-Century America
text: A special session. Presiding: Jillian Spivey Caddell, Cornell Univ.
Speakers: Jillian Spivey Caddell; Melissa Gniadek, Rice Univ.; Coleman Hutchison, Univ. of Texas, Austin; Matthew Wilkens, Univ. of Notre Dame; Gretchen Woertendyke, Univ. of South Carolina, Columbia

This roundtable reassesses the turn to critical geography in nineteenth-century United States literary studies through the conference theme on sites of memory. We interpret the "site” in varying scales to ask how texts generate and erase memory. Panelists present brief provocations followed by discussion on the spatial turn while offering new ways of using the rhetoric of geography to interpret texts.

text: Program arranged by the Division on Poetry. Presiding: Alan Golding, Univ. of Louisville
Speakers: Ardis R. T. Butterfield, Yale Univ.; Roland Greene, Stanford Univ.; Simon Jarvis, Univ. of Cambridge; Meredith Martin, Princeton Univ.; Mark D. McMorris, Georgetown Univ.

In this historically inclusive roundtable, we are defining rhyme and rhythm quite capaciously, as, essentially, "anything having to do with sound patterns." Rhythm in our title is a way of gesturing toward everything having to do with prosody, intonation, "music," oral performance, and extending to the effects of procedurally based repetitions.

title: Transnational Memories: Sites, Knots, Methods
text: A special session. Presiding: Gillian L. Whitlock, Univ. of Queensland
Speakers: Rosanne M. Kennedy, Australian National Univ.; Ann Rigney, Utrecht Univ.; Michael Rothberg, Univ. of Illinois, Urbana; Debarati Sanyal, Univ. of California, Berkeley

The development of the field of memory studies was linked from the outset to national memory cultures, institutions, and sites. With the recent turn toward transnational approaches, however, the concept of "sites of memory" has come under pressure as the assumed framework for the field. This roundtable explores the consequences of the transnational turn for the study of cultural memory.
For abstracts, visit hgmsblog.weebly.com after 15 Dec.

title: Re-remembering Feminism: Narrative, History, Disciplinarity
text: A special session. Presiding: Astrid Henry, Grinnell Coll.
Speakers: Leah Claire Allen, Duke Univ.; Katherine Costello, Duke Univ.; Astrid Henry; Jen McDaneld, Univ. of Portland
Respondent: Jane Gallop, Univ. of Wisconsin, Milwaukee

This roundtable considers the ways in which the tools and practices of literary studies can be used to examine the political effects of feminist narratives. How does remembering the feminist past shape the feminist future? The speakers invite a conversation about the value of, and methods for, generating new understandings of twentieth- and twenty-first-century feminism and its retrospective narratives.

This roundtable investigates the increasingly prominent role of Twitter in literary culture and the profession. Participants offer brief presentations on literary adaptation on Twitter, tweets as identity performance, and Twitter-related pedagogical strategies, followed by a discussion of the usefulness of the platform in scholarship and teaching.

This roundtable analyzes interdisciplinary approaches to studying comics. Comics theory includes semiotics, film theory, linguistics, visual studies, and narrative theory, among other disciplines. The scholars examine to what extent these discourses are in conversation with one another and seek connections among them.

text: A special session. Presiding: Julia McAnallen, Michigan State Univ.
Speakers: Alvin Henry, Masters School; Christina Mesa, Stanford Univ.; Julie Sievers, Saint Edward’s Univ.

The MLA has paid increasing attention to the fluctuating landscape of the humanities PhD, including the rise of digital humanities and the alt-ac movement. We propose to further these discussions and address what it means to be a humanities PhD beyond the professoriat. The goal is to share our experiences and discuss how to promote positive social change as public intellectuals in alt-ac careers.

Given that literary history has largely been configured on the basis of nation, genre, and period, how does chronicling the literary expression of same-sex desire require us to rethink literary history as a critical and scholarly practice? This roundtable advances debate about why we need a history of LGBTQ literature now.

During this interactive session, participants explore a design framework for the integration of technology in the humanities classroom. Examples will be given for all levels of instruction and will focus on place-based learning and digital literacy. Upon completion of the session, participants will have a working model for integration in their own teaching and learning contexts.

title: Dada at the Margins
text: A special session. Presiding: Nicola Behrmann, Rutgers Univ., New Brunswick

Speakers: Helen Adkins, Berlin, Germany; Christopher Butterfield, Univ. of Victoria; Jan Gerstner, Universität Bremen; Jeffrey Hogrefe, Pratt Inst.; Kathryn McEwen, Michigan State Univ.; Andres Zervigon, Rutgers Univ., New Brunswick

The Dada movement has pushed the radical destruction of representation and authorship to its limits. But Dada has also produced its own system of inclusions and exclusions: Who counts as a member of Dada, and who does not? What is regarded as Dada, and what not? In what ways has the exclusion of individual participants from Dada been established through historiography itself?

title: "Real" Old English?
text: Program arranged by the Division on Old English Language and Literature. Presiding: Stephen J. Harris, Univ. of Massachusetts, Amherst
Speakers: Mary Blockley, Univ. of Texas, Austin; David Hadbawnik, Univ. at Buffalo, State Univ. of New York; Tristan Major, Qatar Univ.; Eric Weiskott, Boston Coll.
Respondent: Elaine Treharne, Stanford Univ.

Issues of Old English in the profession today, particularly criteria by which the field judges texts, scholars, and scholarship. What is considered “real” or really important? How might the field rethink old priorities, given new publication formats, the breakdown of hierarchies, digital pedagogy, huge language databases, and a changing relationship between the academy and the public?

title: Literary History and Ideas of Mind
text: A special session. Presiding: Josh Gang, Univ. of Toronto
Speakers: Claire Laville, Emory Univ.; John Savarese, Univ. of California, Berkeley; Nikki Skillman, Indiana Univ., Bloomington; Judith Stoddart, Michigan State Univ.
Respondent: Josh Gang

What is the place of "mind" in literary history? How might histories of cognition change the way we think about questions such as period, genre, and form? Spanning a number of different historical fields, national literatures, and methodologies, this roundtable hopes to use "mind" as a way of connecting literary history, contemporary theory, and the future of literary study.
For abstracts, panelist biographies, and online discussion, visit literature-and-mind.weebly.com.

title: What We Talk about When We Teach about Meter: Alternative Approaches
text: A special session. Presiding: Michael Hansen, Univ. of Chicago
Speakers: Thomas Cable, Univ. of Texas, Austin; Natalie E. Gerber, State Univ. of New York, Fredonia; Meredith Martin, Princeton Univ.; Summer Star, San Francisco State Univ.

Recent work in historical poetics has recovered lost ways of thinking about meter, while scholars drawing on cognitive science, linguistics, and philosophy are producing entirely new analytic methods. Yet the way we teach meter remains largely unchanged. This roundtable addresses this gap between scholarship and teaching through demonstrations of pedagogical alternatives to foot-substitution prosody.
